Rate-Privacy-Storage Tradeoff in Federated Learning with Top r𝑟r Sparsification

Sajani Vithana   Sennur Ulukus
Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering
University of Maryland, College Park, MD 20742
spallego@umd.edu   ulukus@umd.edu
Abstract

We investigate the trade-off between rate, privacy and storage in federated learning (FL) with top r𝑟r sparsification, where the users and the servers in the FL system only share the most significant r𝑟r and r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime} fractions, respectively, of updates and parameters in the FL process, to reduce the communication cost. We present schemes that guarantee information theoretic privacy of the values and indices of the sparse updates sent by the users at the expense of a larger storage cost. To this end, we generalize the scheme to reduce the storage cost by allowing a certain amount of information leakage. Thus, we provide the general trade-off between the communication cost, storage cost, and information leakage in private FL with top r𝑟r sparsification, along the lines of two proposed schemes.

I Introduction

In federated learning (FL) [1, 2], a set of users remotely train an ML model using their own local data in their own devices, and share only the gradient updates with the central server. This reduces the privacy leakage of users while decentralizing the processing power requirements of the central server. However, it has been shown that the gradients shared by a user leak information about the user’s private data [3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8].

Apart from the privacy leakage, another drawback of FL is the significantly large communication cost incurred by sharing model parameters and updates with millions of users in multiple rounds. One solution to this problem is gradient sparsification [9, 10, 11], where the users only communicate a selected set of gradients and parameters as opposed to communicating all gradient updates and parameters. Top r𝑟r sparsification [11] is a widely used sparsification technique, where only the most significant r𝑟r fraction of parameters/updates are shared between the users and the central server, which significantly reduces the communication cost, since r𝑟r is typically around 10−2superscript10210^{-2} to 10−3superscript10310^{-3}.

However, in sparsified FL, the values as well as the positions of the sparse updates leak information about the user’s local data. Note that the positions of the sparse updates convey information about the most and least significant sets of parameters for a given user leaking information about its private data. Thus, in order to guarantee the privacy of users participating in the sparse FL process, two components need to be kept private, namely, 1) values of sparse updates, 2) positions of sparse updates. Reference [12] presents a scheme that achieves information theoretic privacy of the values and positions of the sparse updates in the context of federated submodel learning (FSL) [13, 14, 15, 16, 17]. The scheme in [12] incurs a significant storage cost. In this work, we extend the scheme in [12] to FL, with an additional variable that allows the storage cost to decrease at the expense of a certain amount of privacy leakage.

In this paper, we consider an FL setting with multiple non-colluding databases storing the ML model, and a user that communicates with the databases as shown in Fig. 1. The schemes we propose are based on permutation techniques, where a coordinator initializes a random permutation of sets of parameters, and sends it to the users. The coordinator then places noise added permutation reversing matrices at each database in such a way that the databases learn nothing about the underlying permutation. All communications between the user and the databases take place in terms of the permuted indices, which guarantee the privacy of the positions of the sparse updates. Despite the added noise which ensures privacy, the parameters in each database get placed in the correct place.

The main challenge of this method is the significant storage cost incurred by the large permutation reversing matrices. We propose schemes that reduce the storage cost by reducing the size of the permutation reversing matrices, at the expense of a given amount of information leakage. This is achieved by dividing the ML model into multiple segments and carrying out permutations within each segment; see Figs. 2 and 3. The number of segments is chosen based on the allowed amount of information leakage and the storage capacity of the databases.

In this work, we propose two schemes to perform private FL with top r𝑟r sparsification for uncoded storage. We present the trade-off between the communication cost, storage complexity and information leakage in private FL with sparsification.

II Problem Formulation

We consider an FL setting in which an ML model consisting of L𝐿L parameters belonging to P𝑃P subpackets is stored in N𝑁N non-colluding databases. The parameters take values from a large enough finite field 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q}. A given user at a given time t𝑡t trains the model using the user’s local data. We consider sparsification in both uplink and downlink, to reduce the communication cost. In particular, the sparsification rates of the reading (downlink) and writing (uplink) phases are given by r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime} and r𝑟r, respectively. In the reading (download) phase, the users only download a selected set of P​r′𝑃superscript𝑟′Pr^{\prime} subpackets determined by the databases.111These subpackets are determined based on the sparse updates received at time t−1𝑡1t-1, or by any other downlink sparsification protocol. In the writing (upload) phase, each user only uploads the most significant P​r𝑃𝑟Pr subpackets to the databases.222We assume that all parameters in the sparse set of P​r𝑃𝑟Pr subpackets in the writing phase have non-zero updates.

Note that the users send no information to the databases in the reading phase. Therefore, no information about the user’s local data is leaked to the databases in the reading phase. However, the users send the sparse updates and their positions (indices) to the databases in the writing phase to train the model. Information about the user’s local data can be leaked to the databases from these updates and their indices. In this work, we consider the following privacy guarantees on the values and the positions of the sparse updates.

Privacy of the values of sparse updates: No information on the values of the sparse updates is allowed to leak to any of the databases, i.e.,

I​(Δi[t];Gn[t])=0,n∈{1,…,N},formulae-sequence𝐼superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑖delimited-[]𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑛delimited-[]𝑡0𝑛1…𝑁\displaystyle I(\Delta_{i}^{[t]};G_{n}^{[t]})=0,\quad n\in\{1,\dotsc,N\}, (1)

where Δi[t]superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑖delimited-[]𝑡\Delta_{i}^{[t]} is the i𝑖ith sparse (non-zero) update of a given user at time t𝑡t and Gn[t]superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑛delimited-[]𝑡G_{n}^{[t]} contains all the information sent by the user to database n𝑛n at time t𝑡t.

Privacy of the positions (indices) of sparse updates: The amount of information leaked about the positions of the sparse updates need to be maintained under a given privacy leakage budget, i.e.,

I​(X[t];Gn[t])<ϵ,n∈{1,…,N},formulae-sequence𝐼superscript𝑋delimited-[]𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑛delimited-[]𝑡italic-ϵ𝑛1…𝑁\displaystyle I(X^{[t]};G_{n}^{[t]})<\epsilon,\quad n\in\{1,\dotsc,N\}, (2)

where X[t]superscript𝑋delimited-[]𝑡X^{[t]} is the set of indices of the sparse subpackets updated by a given user at time t𝑡t. The system model with the privacy constraints is shown in Fig. 1. A coordinator is used to initialize the scheme. In addition to the privacy constraints, we require the following security and correctness conditions for the reliability of the scheme.

Security of the model: No information about the model parameters is allowed to leak to the databases, i.e.,

I​(W[t];Sn[t])=0,n∈{1,…,N},formulae-sequence𝐼superscript𝑊delimited-[]𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑛delimited-[]𝑡0𝑛1…𝑁\displaystyle I(W^{[t]};S_{n}^{[t]})=0,\quad n\in\{1,\dotsc,N\}, (3)

where W[t]superscript𝑊delimited-[]𝑡W^{[t]} is the ML model and Sn[t]superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑛delimited-[]𝑡S_{n}^{[t]} is the data content in database n𝑛n at time t𝑡t.

Correctness in the reading phase: The user should be able to correctly decode the sparse set of subpackets (denoted by J𝐽J) of the model, determined by the downlink sparsification protocol, from the downloads in the reading phase, i.e.,

H​(WJ[t−1]|A1:N[t])=0,𝐻conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝐽delimited-[]𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝐴:1𝑁delimited-[]𝑡0\displaystyle H(W_{J}^{[t-1]}|A_{1:N}^{[t]})=0, (4)

where WJ[t−1]superscriptsubscript𝑊𝐽delimited-[]𝑡1W_{J}^{[t-1]} is the set of subpackets in set J𝐽J of the model W𝑊W at time t−1𝑡1t-1 (before updating) and An[t]superscriptsubscript𝐴𝑛delimited-[]𝑡A_{n}^{[t]} is the information downloaded from database n𝑛n at time t𝑡t.

Correctness in the writing phase: Let J′superscript𝐽′J^{\prime} be the set of most significant P​r𝑃𝑟Pr subpackets of the model, updated by a given user at time t𝑡t. Then, the model must be correctly updated as,

Ws[t]={Ws[t−1]+Δs[t],if s∈J′Ws[t−1],if s∉J′,superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑠delimited-[]𝑡casessuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝑠delimited-[]𝑡1superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑠delimited-[]𝑡if s∈J′superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑠delimited-[]𝑡1if s∉J′\displaystyle W_{s}^{[t]}=\begin{cases}W_{s}^{[t-1]}+\Delta_{s}^{[t]},&\text{if $s\in J^{\prime}$}\\ W_{s}^{[t-1]},&\text{if $s\notin J^{\prime}$}\end{cases}, (5)

where Ws[t−1]superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑠delimited-[]𝑡1W_{s}^{[t-1]} is the subpacket s𝑠s of the ML model at time t−1𝑡1t-1 and Δs[t]superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑠delimited-[]𝑡\Delta_{s}^{[t]} is the update of subpacket s𝑠s at time t𝑡t.

Reading and writing costs: The reading and writing costs are defined as CR=𝒟Lsubscript𝐶𝑅𝒟𝐿C_{R}=\frac{\mathcal{D}}{L} and CW=𝒰Lsubscript𝐶𝑊𝒰𝐿C_{W}=\frac{\mathcal{U}}{L}, respectively, where 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} is the total number of symbols downloaded in the reading phase, 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U} is the total number of symbols uploaded in the writing phase, and L𝐿L is the size of the model. The total cost CTsubscript𝐶𝑇C_{T} is the sum of the reading and writing costs, CT=CR+CWsubscript𝐶𝑇subscript𝐶𝑅subscript𝐶𝑊C_{T}=C_{R}+C_{W}.

Storage complexity: The storage complexity is quantified by the order of the total number of symbols stored in each database.

In this work, we propose schemes to perform FL with top r𝑟r sparsification, that result in the minimum total communication cost and storage complexity, while satisfying all privacy, security and correctness conditions described above.

III Main Result

Theorem 1

Consider an FL model stored in N𝑁N non-colluding databases, consisting of L𝐿L symbols from a finite field 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q}, which are included in P𝑃P subpacekts. The model is divided into B𝐵B segments of equal size (1≤B<P1𝐵𝑃1\leq B<P), such that each consecutive PB𝑃𝐵\frac{P}{B} subpackets are included in each segment. Assume that the FL model is updated by users at each time instance with uplink and downlink sparsification rates (top r𝑟r sparsification) of r𝑟r and r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime}, respectively. Let X^isubscript^𝑋𝑖\hat{X}_{i} be the random variable representing the number of subpackets with non-zero (sparse) updates of the i𝑖ith segment generated by any given user, and let (X~1,…,X~B)subscript~𝑋1…subscript~𝑋𝐵(\tilde{X}_{1},\dotsc,\tilde{X}_{B}) be the random vector representing all distinct combinations of (X^1,…,X^B)subscript^𝑋1…subscript^𝑋𝐵(\hat{X}_{1},\dotsc,\hat{X}_{B}), irrespective of the segment index. Then, the reading/writing costs, storage complexities and amounts of information leakage presented in Table I are achievable.

Remark 1

When B=1𝐵1B=1 (no segmentation), X^1=X~1=P​rsubscript^𝑋1subscript~𝑋1𝑃𝑟\hat{X}_{1}=\tilde{X}_{1}=Pr and the corresponding infromation leakage is zero since P​r𝑃𝑟Pr is fixed and H​(X^1)=H​(X~1)=0𝐻subscript^𝑋1𝐻subscript~𝑋10H(\hat{X}_{1})=H(\tilde{X}_{1})=0. That is, the schemes corresponding to the two cases achieve information theoretic privacy of the values and positions of the sparse updates while incurring the same communication costs stated in Table I.

Remark 2

For a given privacy budget on the positions of the sparse updates given by ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, the optimum number of segments B𝐵B can be calculated by minimizing the storage complexity, such that H​(X^1,…,X^B)<ϵ𝐻subscript^𝑋1…subscript^𝑋𝐵italic-ϵH(\hat{X}_{1},\dotsc,\hat{X}_{B})<\epsilon or H​(X~1,…,X~B)<ϵ𝐻subscript~𝑋1…subscript~𝑋𝐵italic-ϵH(\tilde{X}_{1},\dotsc,\tilde{X}_{B})<\epsilon is satisfied.

Remark 3

Since H​(X^1,…,X^B)𝐻subscript^𝑋1…subscript^𝑋𝐵H(\hat{X}_{1},\dotsc,\hat{X}_{B}) considers all possible values of X^isubscript^𝑋𝑖\hat{X}_{i}, while H​(X~1,…,X~B)𝐻subscript~𝑋1…subscript~𝑋𝐵H(\tilde{X}_{1},\dotsc,\tilde{X}_{B}) only considers distinct sets of {X^i}i=1Bsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript^𝑋𝑖𝑖1𝐵\{\hat{X}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{B}, H​(X^1,…,X^B)>H​(X~1,…,X~B)𝐻subscript^𝑋1…subscript^𝑋𝐵𝐻subscript~𝑋1…subscript~𝑋𝐵H(\hat{X}_{1},\dotsc,\hat{X}_{B})>H(\tilde{X}_{1},\dotsc,\tilde{X}_{B}).

Remark 4

Consider an example setting with P=12𝑃12P=12 subpackets divided into B=1,2,3,4,6𝐵12346B=1,2,3,4,6 segments. Assume that each subpacket is equally probable to be selected to the set of most significant P​r=3𝑃𝑟3Pr=3 subpackets. The behavior of the information leakage for each value of B𝐵B is shown in Fig. 4.

Remark 5

For the first case, one can achieve a lower storage cost at the expense of a higher information leakage by increasing B𝐵B and vice versa. This is because the number of different realizations of the placements of the P​r𝑃𝑟Pr sparse subpackets at the B𝐵B segments increases with B𝐵B when all permutations of the placements are considered. However, when only the distinct placements are considered in case 2 (without permutations), after B=P​r𝐵𝑃𝑟B=Pr, the probability of each realization increases, which in turn decreases the entropy H​(X~1,…,X~B)𝐻subscript~𝑋1…subscript~𝑋𝐵H(\tilde{X}_{1},\dotsc,\tilde{X}_{B}), i.e., the information leakage. Therefore, the storage-privacy leakage trade-off in case 2 also follows an inverse relation. The variation of the privacy leakage and the storage cost is controlled by the parameter B𝐵B. The communication cost however is independent of B𝐵B, which makes it independent of the storage cost and the privacy leakage.

IV Proposed Scheme

We propose two schemes. Both schemes achieve privacy of the indices of the sparse subpackets by utilizing a permutation technique. In case 1, the model is divided into B𝐵B segments, and the scheme only considers permutations among the subpackets within each segment while revealing the real segment indices of the sparse subpackets. The scheme in case 2 considers permutations within and among segments to reduce the information leakage further. The schemes are presented in terms of examples due to space limitations here.

IV-A Case 1: Single Stage Permutations

Consider an example setting with P=15𝑃15P=15 and B=3𝐵3B=3.

IV-A2 Reading Phase

The databases decide the permuted indices of the P​r′𝑃superscript𝑟′Pr^{\prime} sparse subpackets to be sent to the users at time t𝑡t in the reading phase, by selecting the permuted indices of the most commonly updated P​r′𝑃superscript𝑟′Pr^{\prime} subpackets by all users at time t−1𝑡1t-1. Note that the databases are unaware of the real indices of the sparse subpackets updated by the users in the writing phase at each time instance and only work with the permuted indices in both phases. For example, let the sparse set of permuted subpacket indices chosen by the databases to be sent to the users corresponding to the first segment be V~1={1,3}subscript~𝑉113\tilde{V}_{1}=\{1,3\}. One designated database sends these permuted indices of each segment to the users. The users then find the real indices, using the known permutations, i.e., for segment 1, the real set of indices is given by V1={2,4}subscript𝑉124V_{1}=\{2,4\}.

Then, database n∈{1,…,N}𝑛1…𝑁n\in\{1,\dotsc,N\} sends the corresponding answer by calculating the dot product between the query and the scaled storage of the respective segment as,

=1f1−αn​W1[2]+…+1fℓ−αn​Wℓ[2]+Pαn​(ℓ+1),absent1subscript𝑓1subscript𝛼𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑊1delimited-[]2…1subscript𝑓ℓsubscript𝛼𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑊ℓdelimited-[]2subscript𝑃subscript𝛼𝑛ℓ1\displaystyle\!=\!\frac{1}{f_{1}-\alpha_{n}}W_{1}^{[2]}+\dotsc+\frac{1}{f_{\ell}-\alpha_{n}}W_{\ell}^{[2]}+P_{\alpha_{n}}(\ell+1), (12)

where Dnsubscript𝐷𝑛D_{n} is the diagonal matrix of size P​ℓB×P​ℓB𝑃ℓ𝐵𝑃ℓ𝐵\frac{P\ell}{B}\times\frac{P\ell}{B} given by Dn=diag{Γn−1,…,Γn−1}subscript𝐷𝑛diagsuperscriptsubscriptΓ𝑛1…superscriptsubscriptΓ𝑛1D_{n}=\mathop{\mathrm{diag}}\{\Gamma_{n}^{-1},\dots,\Gamma_{n}^{-1}\} and Pαn​(ℓ+1)subscript𝑃subscript𝛼𝑛ℓ1P_{\alpha_{n}}(\ell+1) is a polynomial in αnsubscript𝛼𝑛\alpha_{n} of degree ℓ+1ℓ1\ell+1. Then, the users obtain the parameters of real subpacket 2, by solving the N𝑁N equations (answers from N𝑁N databases) of the form (12), given that N=2​ℓ+2𝑁2ℓ2N=2\ell+2, which determines the subpacketization as ℓ=N−22ℓ𝑁22\ell=\frac{N-2}{2}. The same procedure is carried out for all sparse subpackets in all segments. The resulting reading cost is given by,

CR=P​r′​(logq⁡PB+logq⁡B)+P​r′​NL=2​r′​(1+logq⁡PN)1−2N.subscript𝐶𝑅𝑃superscript𝑟′subscript𝑞𝑃𝐵subscript𝑞𝐵𝑃superscript𝑟′𝑁𝐿2superscript𝑟′1subscript𝑞𝑃𝑁12𝑁\displaystyle C_{R}\!=\!\frac{Pr^{\prime}(\log_{q}\frac{P}{B}\!+\!\log_{q}B)+Pr^{\prime}N}{L}\!=\!\frac{2r^{\prime}(1\!+\!\frac{\log_{q}P}{N})}{1-\frac{2}{N}}. (13)

IV-A3 Writing Phase

In the writing phase, each user generates non-zero updates for P​r𝑃𝑟Pr most significant subpackets, and sends the noise added combined updates (single symbol per subpacket) along with their permuted subpacket indices and the segment indices to each of the databases. The combined update of some (real) subpacket i𝑖i of segment j𝑗j (to be sent to database n𝑛n, n∈{1,…,N}𝑛1…𝑁n\in\{1,\dotsc,N\}) is given by,

Un[i,j]=∑k=1ℓ∏r=1,r≠kℓ(fr−αn)​Δ~k[i,j]+∏r=1ℓ(fr−αn)​Z[i,j],superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑛𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑘1ℓsuperscriptsubscriptproductformulae-sequence𝑟1𝑟𝑘ℓsubscript𝑓𝑟subscript𝛼𝑛superscriptsubscript~Δ𝑘𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑟1ℓsubscript𝑓𝑟subscript𝛼𝑛superscript𝑍𝑖𝑗\displaystyle U_{n}^{[i,j]}\!=\!\!\sum_{k=1}^{\ell}\prod_{r=1,r\neq k}^{\ell}\!\!\!(f_{r}-\alpha_{n})\tilde{\Delta}_{k}^{[i,j]}\!+\!\prod_{r=1}^{\ell}(f_{r}-\alpha_{n})Z^{[i,j]}, (14)

where Δ~k[i,j]=Δk[i,j]∏r=1,r≠kℓ(fr−fk)superscriptsubscript~Δ𝑘𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑘𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscriptproductformulae-sequence𝑟1𝑟𝑘ℓsubscript𝑓𝑟subscript𝑓𝑘\tilde{\Delta}_{k}^{[i,j]}=\frac{\Delta_{k}^{[i,j]}}{\prod_{r=1,r\neq k}^{\ell}(f_{r}-f_{k})} with Δk[i,j]superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑘𝑖𝑗\Delta_{k}^{[i,j]} being the update of the k𝑘kth symbol of subpacket i𝑖i of segment j𝑗j and Z[i,j]superscript𝑍𝑖𝑗Z^{[i,j]} is a random noise symbol. Note that the addition of Z[i,j]superscript𝑍𝑖𝑗Z^{[i,j]} to the updates in (14) guarantees information theoretic privacy of the values of updates from Shannon’s one time pad theorem. For example, assume that a given user wants to update the real subpackets 2 and 4 from segment 1, subpacket 2 from segment 2, and subpacket 5 from segment 3. Based on the permutations considered in this example, i.e., P~1={2,1,4,5,3}subscript~𝑃121453\tilde{P}_{1}=\{2,1,4,5,3\}, P~2={3,5,2,4,1}subscript~𝑃235241\tilde{P}_{2}=\{3,5,2,4,1\} and P~3={5,2,3,1,4}subscript~𝑃352314\tilde{P}_{3}=\{5,2,3,1,4\}, the user generates the permuted (update, subpacket, segment) tuples given by (Un[2,1],1,1)superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑛2111(U_{n}^{[2,1]},1,1), (Un[4,1],3,1)superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑛4131(U_{n}^{[4,1]},3,1) for segment 1, (Un[2,2],3,2)superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑛2232(U_{n}^{[2,2]},3,2) for segment 2, and (Un[5,3],1,3)superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑛5313(U_{n}^{[5,3]},1,3) for segment 3. Note that there is no permutation in the segment index, and only the subpacket indices within each segment are being permuted. Database n𝑛n, n∈{1,…,N}𝑛1…𝑁n\in\{1,\dotsc,N\} creates permuted update vectors for each segment upon receiving the P​r𝑃𝑟Pr permuted (update, subpacket, segment) tuples. For segment 1, the permuted update vector is given by,

Note from (18) that for segment 1, the two real sparse subpackets 2 and 4 have been correctly updated, while ensuring that the rest of the subpackets remain the same, without revealing the real subpacket indices 2 and 4 to any of the databases. The resulting writing cost is given by,

CW=P​r​N​(1+logq⁡B+logq⁡PB)L=2​r​(1+logq⁡P)1−2N.subscript𝐶𝑊𝑃𝑟𝑁1subscript𝑞𝐵subscript𝑞𝑃𝐵𝐿2𝑟1subscript𝑞𝑃12𝑁\displaystyle C_{W}\!=\!\frac{PrN(1+\log_{q}B+\log_{q}\frac{P}{B})}{L}\!=\!\frac{2r(1+\log_{q}P)}{1-\frac{2}{N}}. (20)

The total storage complexity (data and permutation reversing matrices) is given by O​(L)+O​(L2B2×B)=O​(L2B)𝑂𝐿𝑂superscript𝐿2superscript𝐵2𝐵𝑂superscript𝐿2𝐵O(L)+O(\frac{L^{2}}{B^{2}}\times B)=O(\frac{L^{2}}{B}).

IV-B Case 2: Two-Stage Permutations

In case 1, only the subpacket indices within each segment were permuted, and the real segment indices were uploaded to the databases by the users. In this case, we permute subpacket indices within segments as well as the segment indices to reduce the information leakage. However, this increases the storage cost since the permutation of segment indices requires an additional noise added permutation reversing matrix to be stored in the databases. For case 2, consider an example setting with P=12𝑃12P=12 subpackets (with subpacketization ℓℓ\ell) which are divided into and B=3𝐵3B=3 equal segments.

IV-B1 Initialization

The storage of a single subpacket in this case is the same as (6) with x=ℓ+1𝑥ℓ1x=\ell+1. The coordinator places the B=3𝐵3B=3 permutations and the corresponding noisy permutation reversing matrices similar to case 1. In addition, the coordinator randomly and independently selects a permutation of the B=3𝐵3B=3 segments P^^𝑃\hat{P} and sends it to the users, while placing the corresponding noise-added permutation reversing matrix R^nsubscript^𝑅𝑛\hat{R}_{n} at database n𝑛n, n∈{1,…,N}𝑛1…𝑁n\in\{1,\dotsc,N\}. \begin{bmatrix}b^{[n]}_{3,1}\!\!\!\!&\!\!\!\!&\\ &\!\!\!\!\ddots\!\!\!\!&\\ &\!\!\!\!&\!\!\!\!b^{[n]}_{3,1}\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}b^{[n]}_{3,2}\!\!\!\!&\!\!\!\!&\\ &\!\!\!\!\ddots\!\!\!\!&\\ &\!\!\!\!&\!\!\!\!b^{[n]}_{3,2}\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}b^{[n]}_{3,3}\!\!\!\!&\!\!\!\!&\\ &\!\!\!\!\ddots\!\!\!\!&\\ &\!\!\!\!&\!\!\!\!b^{[n]}_{3,3}\end{bmatrix}\end{bmatrix}. (24)

In order to send the permuted subpacket indicated by (ηp,ϕp)=(i,j)subscript𝜂𝑝subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑝𝑖𝑗(\eta_{p},\phi_{p})=(i,j), each database generates the query given by,

Qn[i,j]=[Γn−1⋱Γn−1]L×L×∑k=1ℓRn​(:,(j−1)​P​ℓB+(i−1)​ℓ+k).superscriptsubscript𝑄𝑛𝑖𝑗subscriptmatrixsuperscriptsubscriptΓ𝑛1missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpression⋱missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionsuperscriptsubscriptΓ𝑛1𝐿𝐿superscriptsubscript𝑘1ℓsubscript𝑅𝑛:𝑗1𝑃ℓ𝐵𝑖1ℓ𝑘\displaystyle Q_{n}^{[i,j]}\!=\!\begin{bmatrix}\!\Gamma_{n}^{-1}\!\!\!\!&\!\!\!\!&\\ &\!\!\!\!\ddots\!\!\!\!&\\ &\!\!\!\!&\!\!\!\!\Gamma_{n}^{-1}\!\!\!\end{bmatrix}_{L\times L}\!\!\!\!\!\times\sum_{k=1}^{\ell}\!R_{n}(:,(j\!-\!1)\frac{P\ell}{B}\!+\!(i\!-\!1)\ell\!+\!k). (25)

Then, the answer is generated by the dot product between the query and the storage as explained in case 1. In order for the user to be able to download the required subpacket using the N𝑁N answers, the system should satisfy N=2​ℓ+4𝑁2ℓ4N=2\ell+4, fixing the subpacketization of case 2 at ℓ=N−42ℓ𝑁42\ell=\frac{N-4}{2}, which results in the reading cost given in Table I for case 2, using a similar calculation as in (13).

IV-B3 Writing Phase

In the writing phase, the user sends the combined updates, permuted subpacket indices and permuted segment indices of the P​r𝑃𝑟Pr most significant subpackets to all databases. Assume that a given user wants to update the P​r𝑃𝑟Pr sparse subpackets identified by the real (subpacket, segment) pairs given by, (ηr,ϕr)={(2,1),(1,2),(3,3)}subscript𝜂𝑟subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑟211233(\eta_{r},\phi_{r})=\{(2,1),(1,2),(3,3)\}. Based on within segment permutations given by P~1=(2,4,3,1)subscript~𝑃12431\tilde{P}_{1}=(2,4,3,1), P~2=(1,3,2,4)subscript~𝑃21324\tilde{P}_{2}=(1,3,2,4), P~3=(3,1,4,2)subscript~𝑃33142\tilde{P}_{3}=(3,1,4,2), and the segmentwise permutation given by P^=(2,3,1)^𝑃231\hat{P}=(2,3,1), the user sends the following (permuted) information to database n𝑛n, n∈{1,…,N}𝑛1…𝑁n\in\{1,\dots,N\},

(Un[ηr,ϕr],ηp,ϕp)={(Un[2,1],1,3),(Un[1,2],1,1),(Un[3,3],1,2)}superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑛subscript𝜂𝑟subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑟subscript𝜂𝑝subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑛2113superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑛1211superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑛3312\displaystyle(U_{n}^{[\eta_{r},\phi_{r}]},\eta_{p},\phi_{p})=\{(U_{n}^{[2,1]},1,3),(U_{n}^{[1,2]},1,1),(U_{n}^{[3,3]},1,2)\} (26)

where the combined updates Un[ηr,ϕr]superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑛subscript𝜂𝑟subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑟U_{n}^{[\eta_{r},\phi_{r}]} are of the form (14). Once the databases receive all permuted (update, subpacket, segment) tuples, they construct the permuted update vector as,

U~n=[Un[1,2],0,0,0,Un[3,3],0,0,0,Un[2,1],0,0,0]Tsubscript~𝑈𝑛superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑈𝑛12000superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑛33000superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑛21000𝑇\displaystyle\tilde{U}_{n}=[U_{n}^{[1,2]},0,0,0,U_{n}^{[3,3]},0,0,0,U_{n}^{[2,1]},0,0,0]^{T} (27)

This vector is then scaled by an all ones vector of size ℓ×1ℓ1\ell\times 1 to aid the rest of the calculations. The scaled permuted update vector is given by U^n=[U~n​(1)⋅1ℓT,…,U~n​(12)⋅1ℓT]Tsubscript^𝑈𝑛superscript⋅subscript~𝑈𝑛1superscriptsubscript1ℓ𝑇…⋅subscript~𝑈𝑛12superscriptsubscript1ℓ𝑇𝑇\hat{U}_{n}=[\tilde{U}_{n}(1)\cdot 1_{\ell}^{T},\dotsc,\tilde{U}_{n}(12)\cdot 1_{\ell}^{T}]^{T}. Then, database n𝑛n, n∈{1,…,N}𝑛1…𝑁n\in\{1,\dotsc,N\} calculates the incremental update using the combined noisy permutation reversing matrix in (24) as U¯n=Rn×U^nsubscript¯𝑈𝑛subscript𝑅𝑛subscript^𝑈𝑛\bar{U}_{n}=R_{n}\times\hat{U}_{n}, which is of the same form as the storage in (6) with x=ℓ+1𝑥ℓ1x=\ell+1. Therefore, the storage at time t𝑡t, Sn[t]superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑛delimited-[]𝑡S_{n}^{[t]} can be updated as Sn[t]=Sn[t−1]+U¯nsuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝑛delimited-[]𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑛delimited-[]𝑡1subscript¯𝑈𝑛S_{n}^{[t]}=S_{n}^{[t-1]}+\bar{U}_{n}.

The storage complexities of data, noise added intra and inter segment permutation reversing matrices are given by O​(L)𝑂𝐿O(L), O​(L2B)𝑂superscript𝐿2𝐵O(\frac{L^{2}}{B}) and O​(ℓ2​B2)=O​(L2​B2N2)𝑂superscriptℓ2superscript𝐵2𝑂superscript𝐿2superscript𝐵2superscript𝑁2O(\ell^{2}B^{2})=O(\frac{L^{2}B^{2}}{N^{2}}), respectively. Therefore, the storage complexity is max⁡{O​(L2B),O​(L2​B2N2)}𝑂superscript𝐿2𝐵𝑂superscript𝐿2superscript𝐵2superscript𝑁2\max\{O(\frac{L^{2}}{B}),O(\frac{L^{2}B^{2}}{N^{2}})\}.

In the two proposed schemes, there exists a positive information leakage when B>1𝐵1B>1, since the numbers of subpackets with non-zero updates in each segment is revealed to the databases (in permuted or non-permuted order). This information leakage is characterized in terms of entropy expressions as shown in Table I, for the two cases separately. The proofs are omitted in this paper due to space limitations.
